ap.org.description: Associated Press provides much of the firsthand news reporting major networks rely on when they add their "spin." AP is more fact, less opinion.
ap.org.name: Associated Press

axios.com.description: No description is available at this time
axios.com.name: Axios

bbc.com.description: The British Broadcasting Corporation is a public service broadcaster in the UK. It is the largest broadcasting organization in the world and is widely regarded as a centrist source.
bbc.com.name: BBC

bloomberg.com.description: No description is available at this time
bloomberg.com.name: Bloomberg

bloomberg.org.description: The news outlet of Bloomberg L.P, which makes financial software for Wall Street. Primarily focusing on business topics, Bloomberg has defined itself as the Chronicle of Capitalism. Some considerit a Lean Right source, but most objective surveys (AllSides included) have affirmed it to be centrist.
bloomberg.org.name: Bloomberg

breitbart.com.description: Initially a news aggregation site, it has evolved to include a network of its own content, including BigHollywood.com, BigGovernment.com, and more. Former White House Chief Strategist Bannon was formerly Breitbart's Executive Chairman. But, despite common knowledge, he did not found the network (conservative entrepreneur Andrew Breitbart did in 2007).
breitbart.com.name: Breitbart

businessinsider.com.description: No description is available at this time
businessinsider.com.name: Business Insider

cbn.com.description: No description is available at this time
cbn.com.name: CBN

cbsnews.com.description: Critics say CBS News has a liberal bias. In the 2008 election, it donated ~1M to Democratic candidates and only ~150K to Republicans. It is the second largest broadcaster in the world (behind BBC).
cbsnews.com.name: CBS News

cnn.com.description:
Though its cable TV partner is historically moderate, CNN Web News has been classified as lean left in recent years. Please see attatched link for more details.
(This is the rating of an independent party, not the opinion of the developer)
cnn.com.name: CNN

csmonitor.com.description: The AllSides community overwhelmingly rated CSM to be a center source. According to its about page, it looks to injure no man, but bless all manking. Despite the word Christian being in the title, this source is well-regarded for its ability to cover multiple angles of every story.
csmonitor.com.name: Christian Science Monitor

dailymail.co.uk.description: British daily tabloid, whose main content is not political, but nevertheless tends to support Conservatives (Republicans in the US, Tories in the UK).
dailymail.co.uk.name: Daily Mail

drudgereport.com.description: Drudge Report mostly aggregates news from other outlets. It has come under fire in the past for sensationalist headlines (ex: Barack Obama "Birther" Narrative) but was also the first to publish the Monica Lewinsky scandal. Its audience is overwhelmingly conservative, but several studies, including a 2005 UCLA study, have noted its inclusion of Leftist views.
drudgereport.com.name: Drudge Report

forbes.com.description: Primary focuses on economic and business topics
forbes.com.name: Forbes

foxnews.com.description: Widely described as favoring the Republican Party, Pew Research Center found that 47% of conservatives turn to Fox as their primary news source. Looking for the quintessential conservative viewpoint to round out your understanding (or already a conservative?) Fox News is your best bet for both!
foxnews.com.name: FOX News

huffpost.com.description: According to AllSides, HuffPost, like MSNBC, self-identifies as overtly liberal.
huffpost.com.name: Huffington Post

journalism.org.description: A branch of Pew Research Center (C)
journalism.org.name: Pew Research Center

msnbc.com.description: In 2013, MSNBC released its revamped official website under the tagline, 'What Progressives Have Been Waiting For' (Source: Washington Times via AllSides)
msnbc.com.name: MSBNC

npr.org.description: Avoids hot-button issues (gun rights, abortion, etc) in favor of news that is important to both 'sides (immigration, healthcare, etc). It avoids emotionally-charged and polarizing language and ensures that its Editorial/Opinion content (which Leans Left) is not easily-confused with its objective news coverage.
npr.org.name: NPR

nypost.com.description: The Post has come under considerable criticism for sensationalism, advocacy, and conservative bias. A survey conducted by Pace University in 2004, found The Post to be the only organization recieving more votes for 'not credible' than 'credible.' It is the 13th-oldest newspaper in the United States.
nypost.com.name: New York Post

nytimes.com.description: No description is available at this time
nytimes.com.name: New York Times

pewresearch.org.description: American think tank organization  primarily aimed at surveying American opinions on topics of public interst. Its information is widely regarded as factual and non-partisan.
pewresearch.org.name: Pew Research Center

politico.com.description: No description is available at this time
politico.com.name: POLITICO

realclearpolitics.com.description: No description is available at this time
realclearpolitics.com.name: Real Clear Politics

reason.com.description: Covers the libertarian perspective (socially liberal, fiscally conservative). AllSides writes favorably about Reason's refreshing coverage in contrast to typical left or right leaning news
reason.com.name: Reason

reuters.com.description: Reuters provides much of the firsthand news reporting major networks rely on when they add their "spin" Reuters is more fact, less opinion.
reuters.com.name: Reuters

salon.com.description: No description is available at this time
salon.com.name: Salon

slate.com.description:
AllSides found that Slate never includes a Right-leaning perspective on its website[.] Opinion pieces on Slate are clearly labeled news, making it unclear [] what is fact and what is opinion. In its new reporting, Slate often uses subjective and emotional words.
(Directly quoted from AllSides; Please click the 'L' icon for more information)
slate.com.name: Slate

spectator.org.description: Conservative news outlet which sometimes appears in tabloid form (1990s-2000s, 2013+)
spectator.org.name: American Spectator

talkingpointsmemo.com.description: No description is available at this time
talkingpointsmemo.com.name: Talking Points Memo

theatlantic.com.description: No description is available at this time
theatlantic.com.name: The Atlantic

thedailybeast.com.description: No description is available at this time
thedailybeast.com.name: Daily Beast

theepochtimes.com.description: No description is available at this time
theepochtimes.com.name: The Epoch Times

theguardian.com.description: A British national newspaper founded tin 1821 to promote liberal interests. A feature editor for the paper was quoted as saying 'it is no secret we are a centre-left newspaper.' It is the fifth most widely-read online newspaper in the world.
theguardian.com.name: The Guardian

thehill.com.description: No description is available at this time
thehill.com.name: The Hill

theintercept.com.description: Devoted to "fearless, adversarial journalism" it refuses to mandate 'balance' when it believes one side is clearly without merit. The Intercept often takes a hard left stance on war and foreign policy.
theintercept.com.name: The Intercept

time.com.description: No description is available at this time
time.com.name: TIME

townhall.com.description: A majority of AllSides voters believed this rating should be 'Lean Right' It describes itself as 'the leading conservative and political opinion websitee.'
townhall.com.name: Townhall

uk.reuters.com.description: UK branch of Reuters. Reuters provides much of the firsthand news reporting major networks rely on when they add their "spin" Reuters is more fact, less opinion.
uk.reuters.com.name: Reuters (UK)

usatoday.com.description: A 2013 Blind Bias Survey (the best rating method available) rated USA Today as Center. Past critics have accused USA Today of a Lean Left bias, particularly in its editorial pieces, but AllSides has consistently rated the organizaton as having a Center bias.
usatoday.com.name: USA Today

vice.com.description: No description is available at this time
vice.com.name: Vice

vox.com.description: The AllSides team found that Vox consistently writes favorably about Left-leaning policies and never includes a Right-leaning perspective.
vox.com.name: Vox

washingtonexaminer.com.description: Previously rated as Solid Right, this outlet has been reclassified because (1) it tends to avoid sensationalist headlines and d (2) does showcase Left-Leaning points of view (even allowing them to be the top headline)
washingtonexaminer.com.name: Washington Examiner

washingtonpost.com.description: Washington Post has been accused of bias towards both sides, but has been found somewhat left-leaning by AllSides. For articles involving Amazon, be aware Jeff Bezos, CEO of Amazon bought the paper for $250 million through his LLC Hash Holdings
washingtonpost.com.name: Washington Post

washingtontimes.com.description: Originally founded to conservatively fight communism, this newspaper defines itself as conservative and primarily targets moderate/ conservatives (center-right)
washingtontimes.com.name: Washington Times

wsj.com.description: While its opinion page and editorial trend Right, the general news source is Centrist. Please click on the 'C' badge for more information from AllSides.
wsj.com.name: Wall Street Journal
